parse.title: Women's Equal Rights Law of Israel (1951)

text.*:
The Women's Equal Rights Law of Israel (1951) was a law passed in the Knesset of Israel in 1951.[1] The Law was made shortly following Israeli Declaration of Independence and has been a source of both praise and criticism by feminists and men alike. Although the term “equal” is used it is not understood the same as the term “equal” would be in the American sense of the word. The Israeli use of the term equal implies according to feminist intellectual Catherine MacKinnon the “Aristotelian notion that equality entails the treatment of likes alike and un-likes differently in accordance with their unlikeness”.[2] This is known as substantive equality known in gender studies circles as "Equal treatment/special treatment" equal opportunity This archaic interpretation of equality is at the heart of modern Israeli thought on gender equality. It was what made possible the restrictive laws prohibiting women from entering combat positions in the Israeli Defense Forces. This line of thinking was also implemented when Israel created the Women's Corps Women's Affairs advisor as a separate unit.[3] The Women's Corps divided soldiers not on their technical skills or occupation (artillery, medic, infantry) but by their gender instead.

Origins[edit]

The origins for the Israeli statute 5711-1951 can be found in the Israeli Declaration of Independence. The Declaration of Israeli Independence is not a binding legal document, and can only express intent.[1] The Declaration says “The State of Israel will maintain complete equality in social and political rights for all citizens, irrespective of religion, race or sex”.[4] This could be seen as Israel’s first mention of sexual equality in their law system. Israel was one of the first countries in the world to include “sex” in anti-discrimination policy.

Law 5711-1951: Objective[edit]

To set principles for the compliance of the utmost equality between women and men, in the standard set by the Declaration of Independence.

Content[edit]

The major tenets of the law consist of trying to set a basis of equality between both men and women in Israel.

  • Article 1 states that men and women will be equal for all legal acts. However, subsections of Article 1 allows for the differentiation between the sexes. It also submits that the intent to discriminate is irrelevant if discrimination is found to have occurred. A final subsection of Article One discusses women and enactments.
  • Article 2 deliberates on the property of women. It commands that property will be treated as if she was “single”. Property acquired by the women before her marriage will not be infringed on by the marriage.
  • Article 3 converses over “Equal Guardianship”. Both parents are the “natural” guardians of their children. If a parent dies then guardianship remains with the living parent. A subsection covers that a competent Tribunal or Court shall not have their right to decide what is best for the child infringed upon.
  • Article 4 has been repealed.
  • Article 5 is about marriage. It claims that law 5711-1951 will not infringe on any person’s permission or prohibition when it involves marriage.
  • Article 6
    • 6A states that a woman has all rights in respect to her own body. However it states that this law will not relax previously held views of what these rights entail (i.e. abortion).
    • 6B outlines that women have the right to protection from sexual violence, harassment, and exploitation. 6C (a) governs proper representation. Women shall be given proper representation on council boards and other public bodies. Preference is also allowed (for women); in a given situation with two qualified candidates (of both male and female genders) preference may be allotted to the woman if it is deemed preferable to have a woman instead in the given situation.

This though has been repealed.

  • 6C (b) explains that if the officials in the “public body” (explained later in the Law as any: Government Ministry, local authority, municipal company, public bodies enacted by law, and government companies, it further states that this applies even if the words “management, board of directors, or council” are not used) which hold only one representative or have “elected representatives” are exempt from these standards.
    • 6C1 (a) is an important. It lays out that women will have representation in matters of formulations of national/international policy. Has the law “Authority for the Advancement of the Status of Women Law 5758-1998” {RED LINK} in it.
      • 6C1 (b) states that the Government (Prime Minister, a Minister, Deputy Minister, or Director General of a Government Ministry or “appropriating body”) will appoint women from every part of the population in appropriate situations.
        • 6C1 (c) All government appointments will be announced and made public prior to them beginning their work.
          • 6C1 (d) If the representation of women was missing or insufficient in any public body these findings will be made known the Authority for the Advancement of the Status of Women Committee, they will also be informed of any changes or results that the appropriating body took to rectify this.
            • 6C1 (e) An annual report over the appointments of women to public bodies will be given to the Authority for the Advancement of the Status of Women Committee by the appropriating body.
    • 6D(a) All women will have the equal right (as men) to “hold any position” or be assigned to any position in the Israeli Defense Forces, this includes the armed forces, police, prison guards and workers, or any other state security institution.
  • Article 7 covers applicability. Specifically that all parts of this Law do not apply when appointing or electing a religious position or a religious tribunal. It also covers that if a party is over the age of 18 and they wish to settle matters outside of civil areas (i.e. religious court) of their own free will then they may do so. They will then be judged by the “laws of their community” and not Israeli civil authorities.
  • 7(a) Amendment to Women’s Equal Rights Law 5765-2000 states that any agreement made before the amendment is still valid.
  • 7(b) The Law (5765-2000) will not deviate from the standards set forth by Control of Financial Service (Benefit Law) 5765-2000 on retirement age, pensions, or other benefits.
  • Article 8 is an amendment of Criminal Law Ordinance of 1936. It says that if a man dissolved his marriage against the will of his wife with no approval by a competent court or tribunal that then obliged the wife to dissolve the marriage then the man is guilty of a felony, and may be punished by up to five years imprisonment.
  • Article 9 The Minister of Justice is responsible for the implementation of this law and its policies.[5]

Legacy[edit]

Israeli Law 5711-1951 has had a lasting legacy on the state of gender equality in Israel and Palestine. It has been revised once in 2000 updating much of the language and giving greater legal authority to the law. Halakha law remains the most difficult of equality issues to navigate today in Israel, even with the updated law 5711-1951. There is no civic marriage in Israel it must be done through the religious courts (Halakha, and Sharia law). However, in 2006 Gay Marriages done abroad were recognized as fit to be registered with the Official Registry in Israel, making what basically constitutes a "common law" marriage.[6]

Halima Brai v Qadi of the Sharia Muslim Court[edit]

In 1955, widowed mother of three Halima Bria, got remarried. Under Sharia Law (which she was married under and in Israel has legal authority in civil cases) a women with children who remarried was no longer seen in Israeli legal terms as the "natural guardian" for her very own children. She was brought to trial by her sister-in-law who was attempting to remove Halima's children from her custody. The only way in which Israeli law can trump a ruling by the religious courts (Islamic, Jewish, or Christian) is if the religious court "intentionally" ignored Law 5711-1951. The Israeli High Court did not side with Halima Bria and her children were removed from her custody.[7] This case was important because it set the legal standard of allowing the various religious courts to have what amounts to near full autonomy in their rulings. This separation of civil and criminal law still is a huge obstacle for those fighting for gender equality in Israel.

Steinberg v Attorney General[edit]

In 1951 shortly after 5711-1951 passed in the Knesset Israel's first sex discrimination case was brought to the High Court of Justice. In this case Haim Steinberg, who was part of the ultra-orthodox Jewish sect called Neturey-Karta, refused to serve in the new Israeli Defense Forces. His argument was that if he was a women of the Neturey-Karta sect he would be given a religious deferment, but because he was a man he was being denied that "right". The court rejected his appeal not because he was a man but on the grounds that his sect did not recognize the state of Israel as being legitimate or having any legal authority.[8] This set important legal precedent for future cases of gender discrimination in the armed forces. It also put into layman's terms the Israel policy of favoring men in their military over women. Israel had/has many loopholes and ways for a women not wishing to serve to take, few such avenues are available for men in Israel.

1986 Defense Service Law[edit]

Was a Law that was amended in 1999 to allow all women access to any position in the Defense Forces that they qualify for. The Law stipulates that both men and women must perform military service for their country, however it is still far easier for a women to be exempted then it is for a man. Women can still be exempted for their own religious or conscientious reasons. They are then supposed to substitute military service for "national service" for their required two years, although this seems to be rarely implemented. Men are subjected to the IDF's discretion if they are allowed to be exempted or not.The only exception being those studying to be rabbis at the country's various yeshivas.[3] These of course are male only and yet another source for dissatisfaction among those demanding gender equality in Israel.
